editionStmt.edition: This early release includes some 500 EEBO-TCP transcriptions of Early Modern plays that have undergone several routines to create an interoperable and algorithmically amenable corpus of Early Modern Drama. Many incompletely or incorrectly transcribed words have been corrected, including obvious printers' errors, but the text has not been proofread word by word. Each word in the text has been identified as a distinct token with its own xml:id and assigned to a lemma, a part of speech, and a standard spelling. Speech prefixes were mapped to unique speaker ID's as "who" attributes of sp elements. elements

div.p: Non satis insidiis est admiranda virago.
London. Printed by Tho. Cotes, for Andrew Crooke; and are to be sold at his shop, at the green dragon, in Paul's churchyard. 1640.

div.head: To his worthy friend, Mr. Robert Chamberlain on his swaggering damsel.
div.l: What pretty humour was thy muse in when,
She put on breeches, and the dress of men;
Casting aside her robe, embroidered thick,
With laurel sprigs, and flowers of rhetoric;
Or what conceit had Mercury, when he,
Made use of Venus' looking-glass to see
How his shape female did become him, sure
She tainted him being herself impure;
No, she is chaste, and in her genial bed,
Hermes himself would lose his maidenhead:
Cupid has stuffed her pillow with loose hairs,
Plucked from his silken curls, and oft repairs
Unto her slumbers with a balmy kiss,
Charming her brain to teem with love like his.
Her sheets are sweetly aired, and spun so fine,
Ladies may have worse lodging, light thy pine
Then glorious Hymen, at our damsels eyes,
That she may shine in her solemnities,
And dazzle her detractors, thou choice friend,
Shall give me leave with justice to commend;
Thy pains to the Pierides, thy hand,
Shalt dress their banks and bowers, until the land
Grow fertile as thy fancy, for thy parts,
Have made a conquest of a thousand hearts.

div.head: To his deserving friend, Mr. Robert Chamberlain upon his swaggering damsel.
div.l: Friend, when my vessel from the narrow stage,
Launched to this wider ocean, where the rage
Of madding censure met her, thou didst play
The part of a skilled pilot calmest the way:
Nor envy with her strongest winds durst stir,
Knowing (Skilled navigator) thou guidest her;
I dare not boast, like art, yet hope to prove
Commended, since I strive to quit thy love
In the acknowledgement, and offer these
To thy fair damsel's welfare, may she please
Those that have judging souls; and to the rest
That hate dramaticke laws, as is your test
Unto their faith, that's hateful, for they be
Counted in show, not prove their purity:
This glory for to suffer their dull rage,
And be cried up the glory of the stage.

div.head: To his deserving friend Mr. Robert Chamberlain upon his swaggering damsel.
div.l: Your swaggering damsel you most aptly fit,
To the sweet harmony of art, and wit,
Your pen hath taught all women to begin,
A new; yet civil way to swagger in;
Our natures you have changed, and men adore,
The selfsame thing which they did hate before;
A woman Cavellier, nor is your muse,
In forfeiting her modesty profuse;
No debauched scenes, nor such base mirth as we
Place in the scenes, of obscene ribaldry,
Pollutes they pen, thy happy influence,
Virgins may read with a safe innocence:
And shall applaud thee as one born to be,
The sole restorer of their liberty.

list.item: Sir Timothy testy; an old angry decayed knight.
Sir plenteous Crambag, an old usurer.
Valentine Crambagge, son to sir plenteous, and lover of Sabina.
Fairefaith, kinsman to Valentine, and lover of Mirabell.
Hilts, a blunt fellow, servant to sir Timothy.
Trash, clown, and servant to Valentine.
Welt, his wife, a shoemaker, at whose house Valentine lay in the time of his disguise.
Roger and Rowland, servants to sir plenteous.

div.head: The prologue.
div.l: Fair stars attend this presence, gentlemen,
Our author bids me bid ye welcome, than
Our house bids welcome, I myself again,
Well, then at once thrice welcome gentlemen.
But first, to you whose education brings
Learning along with't for to judge of things;
I speak, but what needs that, your natures such,
That with nice criticism it scorns to touch.
Ladies for you, I read it in each front;
You will, nay more, you must look fair upon't,
Howe'er , we hope, that all your smiles will be,
Propitious to our labours, not that we,
Forestall your judgements, or do beg applause,
That's not our meaning, we have no such cause;
Yet do believe, you will your candours bring,
Cause 'tis the primrose of the author's spring.

div.head: Actus 1. Scaena 1.
div.stage: Enter Hiles, Roger, and Rowland; Roger with a napkin on his sleeve, and a silver bowl in's hand.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Come hilts, one cup more.

sp.speaker: Hilts,
sp.p: Not a drop, I know they have dined by this time, and if I should be out oth' way, when my master comes, he would rail, that the noise of an oyster wench would not be half so devilish.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Come, come, one lusty dish now ith' bottom oth' cellar's worth all the rest —

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: A way with your number 4. it makes rattle-bags and windmills in my guts, I cannot endure it.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Come, come, I warrant ye, it will not, prithee come.

sp.speaker: Hilt.
sp.p: Not? Why I'm blown with't already like a Lancashire bagpipe upon a may day; and besides, 'tis so weak, that a man cannot keep it alive while he throws it in's guts, when thou com'st 'To our house I'll give thee a cup of beer will make thy nose cry twang Roger.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Why, but ye do not keep such a house for all your jesting, do ye?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Such a house, shalt come in a morning, and find the cellar a foot deep in march beer; here a black Jack, and there a flagon standing in't like steeples in a drowned city — there's housekeeping Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: I marry sir, there's a house well kept indeed.

sp.speaker: Hilts ▪
sp.p: Nay sir, by this means we make my master a better house keeper than ere his father or grandfather was before him; for where they were used to ride every day a hawking and hunting, my master keeps the house sometimes for two or three years together, and what's the cause? nothing but our mirth, our randans, our tarra tantaras — o the only way in the world to make a gentleman a housekeeper.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Well, come, I must needs have our round about to thy master's daughters; for dost hear hilts, methought there was a little nodding and winking betwixt my young master, Mr. Valentine Crambag, and mistress Sabina, didst not perceive it Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Yes marry did I, and tother gentleman there his kinsman methought now and then cast a sheep's eye towards mistress Mirabell; go to, an old ape has an old eye, Roger.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Why but Roger you are not such a sillybrain, I hope to think that your young master loves mistress Sabina —

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Nay, I me passed thinking, for I do partly know it.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: How?

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why, 'tis neither impossible nor unlikely?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I do not believe your young master's such a stout fellow Roger.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Why pray?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p:
I mean, as to venture himself upon such a wild thing, I tell you sirs, your young master, I confess is a pretty dapper young gentleman, but in respect of her he is but a child, a shrimp, a butterfly, a chitterling, a babble; in love with her quoth 'a? She's not one that cares for compliments, or will be won with cringes, or your tres-humble serviteur madame; no no Roger; she is a blade, a spark, a tear-coat; and he that carries her away, must mumble her, jumble her,
rumble her, and tumble her, swagger, roar, and tear like a mad man; your young master quoth 'a? — pish,

div.stage: To them Valentine and Fairefaith.

sp.speaker: Rog.
sp.p: Husht, here come the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why stand you here? make sir Timothy testies man welcome — go.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: It was a brave speech of your worship's sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O cousin,Exit with Rog. and Row.
The womb of Aetna's but a rock of ice,
Compared unto those flames that rage within
My bosom;
I must enjoy, or else give end unto
This mortal life by some untimely means.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Good stars forbid it sir;
Come, come,
Lull not your own destruction, nor unman
Yourself in doting on the outward frame
Of an imperfect soul,
Follow discretion's finger that will guide
Your understanding and your mind to one,
Whose person's virtues temple;
Cousin think on't,
Her qualities and yours will never agree;
Your civil nature never will correspond
With her wanton humours.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: It cannot be,
There's nothing save a deity can inhabit
So glorious a mansion,
Not love her, say ye? not have her;
I hope my stars will never look so black,
However yet my comforts this,
If I cannot have her I can perish.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: That case is desperate, when a man must needs
Sink in a gulf, or split upon the rock;
Know sir, I bear as good a mind
To her fair sister Mirabell; but yet
I check these passions fearing that she is
Too like her sister, yet my flames do rise
so high, that she takes notice on't; come
Learn to forget her, for you must expect
Nothing from her but scorn.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: That such a creature has so foul a soul,
'Twill never pierce
My understanding judgement, or belief;
Her birth and education needs must purge
Such grossness.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir be happy, hug your own fancy,
May things prove well, I shall be glad to see't;
Far be't from me to envy any good
Betides a friend and kinsman. To them Sabina Mirabell.
Peace, they're both come.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Welcome fair one,
Welcome I say, toth' arms of him that flies,
All joys but those that in thy bosom lies.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: My bosom? what d'ye you find there pray sir; you have a mind perhaps to my jewel, if you will not hurt it, ye shall have it a while to play with, 'tis a pretty bright thing sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not so bright as your white bosom, lady.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: As how pray ye? what see you there?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O no, the gods would frown if any mortal breath,
Should once profane that milky way,
There's not a little in that lovely place,
But does create a wonder:
When Cupid's thirsty, and desires a sip,
Of nectar, than he runs unto thy lip,
And for your hair, the brightness of it does
Persuade my soul the very graces spun
The golden twist.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray ye speak on sir, when ye have emptied your pockets you'll be quiet.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Emptied my pockets?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Sir, these are but pocket compliments, run 'em over once, and then perhaps I shall talk with ye; remember where ye left, I would be loath to put ye out sir, my hair was golden twist, ye said, come, what of all this?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This has inflamed my thoughts,
Ensnared my soul, and made me vow
A desperate destruction to myself,
Except from you I have one gracious smile
May style me servant;
And for your father's mind,
I know it jumps with our desires.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: My father's mind? d'ye think his frosty beard,
Can temper my affections,
No, no,
His precepts are too withered for my youth;
Know sir,
That I disdain those low-born worms
That will be circumscribed by dotage
In loves affairs: I scorn to be directed,
I am myself sir, and my only soul
Is my own will and humour:
But pray whence come these words?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: From my deep passions.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Whence those passions.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: From your fair eyes, they
Were the happy guiders of my soul,
Unto this bower of wonder;
They fired my heart
Which burns, and will do in remorseless flames,
Until from them I do receive a glance,
May sweeten these my torments.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Not so loud I pray you, speak softly sir. They whisper.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Speak Mirabell,
May I think a proud thought.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O by no means sir, they are great sins.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: This of mine's a virtue.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What may it be sir?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Nothing lady, but a presumptuous study to be yours.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, you may speak what you please, but first
Let it arrive my apprehension what
Or how you mean, according to my skill,
I will return my answer.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Only to be
One of the number that do still attend
Your pleasure's beck, and so be styled your servant.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir,
My thoughts nor fortunes ever were so high,
To keep a servant of that consequence,
And 'tis my hope they never will, or shall be.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Break not a sacred oath, for I have sworn
Myself your servant: then for pities sake,
Do not infringe my vow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well,
Tendering your vow, suppose I should admit
Yourself into my service, would ye strive,
To express the faith and diligence belongs
Unto a servant.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: My pleasure and delight should fix,
On nothing more than to express,
My faith and loyalty.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Well, I admit you into my service,
But by the way you may perhaps observe
Some passages betwixt a friend and me,
As letters, tokens passages, or so;
Which if ye do, take heed ye word it not,
But still possess yourself with secrecy.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Betwixt a friend and you? — umph.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Never scratch your head about it, for you're now my servant.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: I am, I've sworn it, and I will be so,
But yet ye did not hear me swear myself,
A servant to your friend — I'll none of that.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Your reason?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: 'Tis love that makes me here present myself,
And with myself to tender up my soul,
Engaged by vows and oaths to wait upon
No creature but yourself:
Love is the spur that pricks me on to this,
And love you know can brook no rivals.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Do you love and serve yourself?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: You and myself I do.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Yourself's the friend I mean, and this discourse
Has been a true prospective glass, whereby
To peep into your mind, which now I find
Full fraught with sweetness, when I did desire,
Ye would keep private what ye did observe,
'Twas nothing else
But to be secret to yourself and me;
Sir, in a word, I do embrace your love.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Be not too prodigal of thy goodness sweet,
Consider what a scarcity's of it now
Ith' world.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Let this suffice sir, — I am yours.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray let me entreat ye to love yourself a little better than to spend all this breath to no purpose.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Why then I'll take my leave, but first, let this snow white hand but deign to bless the unhallowed lips of your admiring slave, that I may hence with gladness, and have cause to boast of something.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: With all my heart sir; but I pray how long were you doctor of the chair in the school of compliments?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O they can never come from a dejected spirit. Kisses her hand.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Well, now I hope you are satisfied.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I wish my heart could truly speak it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, come, you are too importunate.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O let not anger bend so smooth a brow,
Not for the earth's hid mineral would I give
The least occasion of a frown to thee,
For if I should,
I should perpetually abhorring myself
Though not a word,
Yet let me have one glance before I go,
For nothing fair one speaks a lover's mind,
So well as the eye,

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: They talk of women, but you are able to teach all the women in the world to talk much to little purpose, for ought I see; come I must tutor ye a little, I see that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p:
Were I so happy to be your pupil, I were a wonder
to myself.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: If it were so I think you would not be much troubled to make him untruss forsooth.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: For pities sake jest not at pities object:
Little knowest thou the miseries of him,
That has his amorous flames returned with scorn:
Well, since 'tis thus, I will myself translate
From this mortality, and embrace my fate.

div.stage: To them sir Timothy testy, sir plenteous crambagge.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: No further, no further, pray return.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Good sir give me leave to bring you a little further.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Pray ye, return, ye do but trouble yourself and me to no purpose, well, sir plenteous Crambag I thank ye.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Farewell good sir Timothy testy.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Come girls, come — where's hilts? — ha. Where is he?
Where are you sir, when ye should wait upon me? — ha, where I say?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I was but ith' cellar, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: Ith' cellar forsooth? what business have you ith' cellar for sooth? who should wait upon me the whilst? wherefore do I give you three pound a year, and a trencher-cloak? — ha? — well —

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Farewell sir plenteous,

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Farewell good sir Timothy testy. Exit sir Tim. cum suis.how does my cousin Fairefaith? how shall we squander away this afternoon, can you tell?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: As you please sir.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Come, I have a mighty mind to be merry, whatsoe'er the matter is.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: I'm very glad of it sir.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: But I have always observed that when I am so extremely disposed to mirth, one vexation or other falls presently in the very nick.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: It falls so sometimes sir.

sp.speaker: Sir. P.
sp.l: Well come, what d'ye say gallants?
My thoughts methinks are on a jocund pin,
I am strained up to a mighty pleasant key, methinks .

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What say you cousin Valentine?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What ye please.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Nay, i' me indifferent, my masters walk the fields.
Go by water, see a play, or what ye will, 'tis
All one to me, come what say you son, — speak?
Which of these three, come, come, you are too sad ▪
Say, what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What ye will sir, I confess I do sometimes walk the fields, thinking to purge vexatious thoughts, but wheresoever I turn mine eye, something or other ministers occasion of fresh tortures: when I go by water, than the waves that tumble one in the others neck, present to my fancy the multiplicity of distraction crowding in at the door of my thoughts, and for seeing a play, I confess it a brave thing, both to feast the wit, and recreate the mind: but, I think I shall ere be long see myself act my own tragedy.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: I told you cousin, this sunny flash would have a storm;
What's the matter son? — ha? —
Why thus dejected? —
Speak — cousin, what is the business?
What ails my son?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: No great hurt sir.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Speak man, here's none but friends, unbreast yourself, what's the matter I say?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing sir, only a melancholy fit.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Nothing? that's strange — cousin, how comes my son thus discontented? what would he have?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Sir, to stretch your patience no further than it will reach, 'tis a gentlewoman that he would have, a good lusty handsome gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: A gentlewoman? how d'ye mean a gentlewoman? What would he do with her cousin?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: I cannot tell sir, he has a use for her it seems, he is in love with her, you may imagine now what he would do with her.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: How? in love with a gentlewoman?
You are a forward boy indeed — I hope
'Tis with one that hath a good portion, if not youth by
Gold and silver, you and I shall not be friends — umph:
In love quoth 'a? It is a thing cousin, I never yet knew
What it was, and yet I'm three score and upwards.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.l: Not sir,
Were ye not in love with your lady before ye married her?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: 'Tis true, I had a great deal of money with her.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: More than your son's like to have with this gentlewoman I hear.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Say ye so? how comes this about son? — ha? Is't possible?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir,
'Tis not this transitory pelf,
Nor all the trumpery the world cries up
That I respect; no, I esteem a soul
Sweetened with education;
Let dung admirers idolise their bags;
'Tis not for man,
In whom there dwells an immortality:
I have made a choice,
Not for such by respects, this creature is
The pride and darling both of love and fame:
Sir, know that I
Scorn to dishonour my good stars so far,
As to besmear my soul with trash,
Or to profane loves sacred rites for wealth.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Come, come, tell not me of education, and I cannot tell what, I must have money, I cannot purchase land
With education not I, neither with all your
Philosophy, I tell you, I must have
Money, and I will have money — but prithee cousin what is this
Gentlewoman — ha?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: A brave lusty bouncing lass, I can ell ye — what d'ye think of mistress Sabina testy, daughter to sir Timothy testy.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: What of her?

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: She is the goddess of your son's idolatry.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: She? Passion of my heart, son, couldst thou find nobody else to dote on but she? did I cark, and care, and watch, and toil and moil, and sweat for this — ha? have I endured a thousand millions of curses for exacting of forfeitted bonds, and mortgaged lands for this? Sir Timothy testy's daughter, quoth 'a? A wild slut, her father a decayed gentleman, and one that with riot and excess has cut so many collops out of his estate, that sometimes he is glad to keep his chamber, and gentily begin a course of physic two or three years together, sir Timothy testy's daughter quoth 'a?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O my heart, methinks it tears in a thousand shivers, mistress — father — friends, and all averse to my desires, be not so cruel fates.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Well, to be short, if sir Timothy can, or will, give a considerable portion, 'tis a match, if not, pardona moy, good son, I will not have a brood of beggars in my house — not I.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Stay a little sir, the greatest matter you do not either know, or consider, were your consent the thing, that I think would not be much stood upon; but here comes the break neck of the business; the gentlewoman scorns him.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: How? scorn the crambags? Sir, be it known to all men by these presents, that there's never a gentleman of 'em all but are now and then glad to be beholden to the crambags; she scorn him? come cousin, I'll go talk with her father about it, but first I'll know her portion.

div.stage: Exeunt sir Plen. and fair.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis in vain, she cannot love, not? why can she not love? am I so vile a thing? no, I am not, what's the reason then? 'tis her immortal mind that wings her thoughts above my reach, there, there 'tis; what shall I do then? turn coward and suffer it; nay, what can I do — what? I can die —
sp.l: Oh ye fields of bliss,
If ye contain a flowery grove of rest,
Prepared for those that must needs die for love,
Embrace my vows, and entertain that soul
that flies for shelter to your sacred shades,Offers to draw.
Come forth thou purge of melancholy,
Rip up this lump of sadness, cut those chains,
Wherewith my soul is linked to misery;
— stay, — come down proud thoughts,
Consider well what ye attempt to do:
Am I a sacrifice for such a wight?
— oh no, I'll then resolve to live,
Although it be but to torment myself,
And think that torment pleasure, cause 'tis she,
For whom alone I suffer misery.

div.head: Actus secundus.
div.stage: Enter sir Timothy testy, sir plenteous crambagge.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Pish, pray sir do not urge me, I'm a little busy.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: 'Tis but a word sir, and the matter ends.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Words, or matter, I cannot hear it now I tell ye.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: 'Tis a concernment requires your serious intention, as much as mine sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Sir, I do not use to step out of my humour, neither for my own sake, nor no man's else.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: 'Tis for your own profit and good, pray hear it sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, let's here it then, let's hear it, but d'ye hear, be brief.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Thus it is.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Nay, come come, make an end, make an end.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I have not begun yet sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Prithee make an end I say.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Well, than you shall hear the end: my son Valantine has a mind to make a conjunction copulative with your daughter Sabina.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Speak in a plainer part of speech man, what d'ye mean?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: He has a mind to lie with her sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: I'll see him hanged first, except he marry her first.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: So he does intend sir, but you would not hear the beginning, which made me begin at the end.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, come to th'point, what says my daughter to't?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Rich parents never question that sir, they first wisely agree upon portions, seal writings, then marry the young couple, and afterwards, give 'em time to consider of that, if we may have your consent, I make no question of hers.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, ye have it, ye have it.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I thank ye sir, I shall make my son a glad man when I come home sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Send 'em joy, come, is this all ye have to say?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: 'Tis all sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Stay sir, I had like to have forgotten the main business.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Puh, yet again, speak, speak come, what is't?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I would desire to know sir what blessings you mean to bestow upon your daughter?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Pish, d'ye think I'll be backward in these things? She shall have a thousand.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: 'Tis a fair portion sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Have ye done now?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: I have done, I have done, heavens protect ye sir —

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: A due, a due.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: — Good sir, but one word more, and then I have done.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What again, what ails the man trow?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Only this sir, I hope you'll pay the money upon the wedding day sir, will not ye?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Money? — what money?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: The marriage money sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What marriage money?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: The thousand pound.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: The thousand pound? what d'ye mean sir?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Did you not say but now you would give a thousand pound with her?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I told you I would give her a thousand blessings; passion of my heart, a thousand pound quoth 'a? sir I scorn it; ye have abused me to think so, let those scraping curmudgeons, that for the most part beget cripples and idiots like themselves, I say, let those do't i tell ye; on the wedding day, as I said, I'll give her a thousand blessings with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: And never a penny of money?

sp.speaker: Sir.
sp.p: Not a penny.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: What? Not with your own child?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Not a denier, not one denier:

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Why then give me leave to tell ye, your resolution is unworthy, nay, 'tis scurvy.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How scurvy? and in my own house too?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Ay scurvy, and I must tell ye, argues no better than a beggarly disposition.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Beggarly disposition? O baseness itself.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Base, I ne'er stood yet sir with my cap in my hand to a scrivener for the procuring of ten pounds upon my own bond.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How? I stand with my cap in my hand ye rascal? when? when? how? to whom? I stand with my cap in my hand? — I defy thee. Enter hilts.I stand with my cap in my hand?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: How now? what d'ye affront my master in's own house sir, pray avoid.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Out of my house ye dunghill, ye dirt, ye spawn of ten ith' hundred.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Come, come sir, let's see your back, or your worship's pate feel the weight of my cudgel.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Out ye villain.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Very well sir. Exit sir plenteous.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: A slave abuse me thus, and in my own house too.

sp.speaker: Hil.
sp.l: Come sir, do not trouble yourself, he's gone now

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: A sirrah, an old Pancridge.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Nay I see you are bell mettle sir if you're angered once.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Angry? 'twas well thou cam'st in, for in my conscience I had killed the rogue else. Enter Sabina, Mirable.whoreson dogbolt affront me thus.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: What's the matter hilts, who has vexed my father thus

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p:
Old Crambag forsooth, has been here and so abused me as I was never abused since I peeped into the world, and what's the reason forsooth, because his son and heir's in love with you forsooth, and intends to make you his bride forsooth, therefore must I give t'him a thousand pound forsooth, but I'll see him hanged for a sign at's own door first; the truth is
daughter, his son is a pretty gentleman, but here's the thing, his son, as I perceive is mad in love, and for ought I see, rather than fail, he will give me a thousand pound for my consent, were not I an ass than hilts, to give a man a thousand pound to marry my daughter; when the same man rather than go without her will give it me? were not I a buzzard then I say?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: A man would think so sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Why shod I do it — ha? give me but a why, and I'm satisfied?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: In troth sir I cannot give you any great reason, unless your purse were sick of a pleurisy which I cud never find yet.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: Well, for the business of marriage, use your own mind daughter, I cannot tell, perhaps the old cur may leave him an estate — well, once trouble not me, and do your pleasure, but if you talk of money, I shall be angry, come along hilts. Exit sir T.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: This young gentleman, a nimble spark I see, that I did not think the young colt would have been leaping so quickly — therefore do you hamper him as soon as ye can, d'ye hear.

sp.speaker: Within.
sp.p: Come away hilts.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I'm coming and please your worship. Exit Hil.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Advise me in this dangerous maze to steer a safe course.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Ye are in a fair way to do yourself a great deal of good, keep yourself in't sister, the gentleman's a great heir, sweetly behaved, bravely discoursed ▪ and besides, a proper handsome complete gentleman, what can you desire more sister?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Sister, I love the gentleman, at first, I confess, I did a little sleight him, but my second thoughts framed a recantation which my intentions have directed to salute him speedily.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A way with it sister, give it not a minute's more entertainment for a world, send it immediately.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, I'll dispatch it instantly.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Be certain ye do sister. Exeunt Sab. Mir.

div.stage: Enter Valentine, Fairefaith, Sportlove, Trash.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: — umph,
And was I born to the sport of fate,
Cud not the destinies as well have said
Be happy
— inexorable stars,
Had ye but doomed me to have trod the paths
Of dreadful banishment never to return,
T'had been a heaven in respect of this
— but 'tis in vain,
Upon the statutes of the stars to plain;
I must even rush upon some desperate death,
And there's an end.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Heavens forbid sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: There's no remedy, her loves impossible.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Impossible? why d'ye think the world contains a creature cannot be won.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes indeed?

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: You might as well have told me, that he that has a puritanical wife cannot be a cuckold sir; take this from me, there's not the bravest gallant that e'er went naked to the middle, but a handsome man, good clothes, language, and money will bring her under the see, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Sir, methinks it were not a miss if you did cast your eye upon some other, the world is wide and populous, and now and then to look a squint, would be a good way to assuage the violence of your passion.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O no, she — she is the blazing star where on I gaze, and the little world of beauty which I admire.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O brave master — there was a speech; oh master Sportlove, this learning's a dainty matter — d'ye hear sir, shall I go and tell her what ye say? —

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: You cannot come again time enough, let it alone.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I warrant ye sir. Exit Trash.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Come, try her again sir, ye cannot tell, drops of rain may pierce an adamant.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: That's with often falling upon't sir, if he cud but learn that, she would love him presently.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Push, away with these fruitless passions, be yourself once again.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: That cannot be sir, you must consider he is in love.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Why, cannot a man be in love, and yet be himself too?

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: He may be, but 'tis raro aut nunquam, jealousy in a woman, love in a man, and tooth ache in a dog, are three of the most dangerous things I can tell ye, that are incident to mortals. Enter Trash.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, I'm come again gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: What already, and done your errand too?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: O rarely, sir, I had it as perfect —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sirrah, what did ye tell her? you are so officious.

sp.speaker: Fr.
sp.p: I told her sir, that your worship said, she was the staring blaze whereon you gazed, and the world of little beauty which you admired.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Out ye rogue, ye small knowing rascal, thou hast undone me; did I tell ye so? dost thou go and turn my words backwards, ye villain. Falls upon him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Gentlemen, if I cud run away from him, I would not be beholden to ye, for shame, do not stand still and see a man killed.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: It was but a mistake sir, pray pardon him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Twas nothing sir, but only the wrong end came out first, the gentlewoman understood it well enough.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Come, pray ye sir have patience.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I must kill the rogue, for he will never have wit.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Forbid that sir, if men should be killed for want of wit, I had been a masterless coxcomb long ago sir, but 'tis no matter, you may use me at your pleasure.

sp.speaker: Sp.
sp.p: Come, come, all's well, all's well.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I that's true indeed, when I'm beaten once, then all's well still.

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: But Mr. Sportlove, nothing but this gentlewoman troubles me, that she should be so fair, so young, so handsome, and yet cannot love — methinks 'tis strange.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: It may be she feeds upon preserved snow, which if she do, she'll seldom have a warm thought, I can tell ye,

sp.speaker: Fa.
sp.p: Nay, her diet's good I'll assure ye, for she will constantly have a breakfast of oringoes, a dinner of potatoes, a sack posset to supper, and so goes to bed.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: If she feed thus, 'tis impossible for the poor gentlewoman to hold out long.

div.stage: Enter Betty with a letter.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Fellow servant, how fares our mistress?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Ye were told but just now, were not ye?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: This letter was commanded first to kiss your hand, and then inform ye.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To the gentle hand of her dearest Valentine address these.

body.head: The letter.
body.p: Val. sir, I hope by this time your good nature has granted a pardon for my seeming rashness, which proceeded not from a mind fraught with disdain, but grounded on a resolution to be your servant, th'old man's not yet in bed, but half an hour's forbearance locks him up in slumber; about which time my ambition is to see you at my chamber, where my servant shall attend to give you access to,

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Now sir you would run into the fire, and drown yourself, would ye? what d'ye think of me now sir, did I not do my errant bravely sir, did not I?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thou hast done ingeniously, and I will study correspondent gratitude.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, pray sir, I had as lief you did beat me again, as give me hard words forsooth, I cannot endure 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O how precious are those minutes wherein are wrapped unexpected joys, sweet piece of paper; fair was that star under whose influence thou wert made — oh this half hour's forbearance, pardon sweet heart, passion had almost made me forget a due respect. Kisses her.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Pray sir do not charge your memory with these things, leave 'em to me sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To you sir, wherefore?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Because she is the sugar-plum — of my affection's sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Cry ye mercy, farewell pretty duck; tell your mistress I will fly like time, till I have blessed these eyes with the sight of her. Exit Betty.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Cousin, you're now in a progress towards the gentlewoman, take a little of my advice along with ye — having now the advantage of a fair opportunity, try her every way, you know my meaning, and then as you find her disposed, you may better dispose of your affections.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Sir, were it in my case, I tell ye in plain terms, I would promise her a thousand things, and it may be for a night's lodging, I would vow 'em and swear 'em too; but when i had once satisfied my purposes, I would show her a fair pair of heels, and there's an end.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Spoken like a gentleman, I'll assure ye sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: 'Tis easy sporting where no pain is felt,
Come, come, let's go.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: We attend your pleasure sir, for I perceive you long to be where your mind is.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: A lack aday, you must consider sir every thing would live.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sweet, I come. Exit Val. Fai.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Didst ever see a passion so transport a man, heavens bless his wits.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Twas a good prayer sir, but he must have 'em first.

div.stage: Exeunt Spo. Trash.
Enter Sabina, Betty.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What said he Betty when he read the letter.

sp.speaker: Bett,
sp.p: He was so ravished with joy, that i think he knew not what he said forsooth, and for the letter, he did so cull it, and lull it, and clip it, and hug it, and buss it — oh me mistress, this love —

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty pleasant vexation; but did he say he would come?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p:
He told me he would come with all speed, and that he should think every minute a hundred years till he saw ye, with many other pretty words which I cannot repeat
for sooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I shall be extreme melancholy till I see him; but are you sure he did say he would come?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Very certain, forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: How long d'ye think it will be first?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Your own appointment was half an hour, but for ought I saw, he was resolved not to forbear so long forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Prithee Betty help me to cozen the time a little with some pretty love song.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: That will but make ye the more melancholy forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Though it do, yet methinks I love it dear.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: methought ye said ye were afraid of being melancholy but now forsooth?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I did so, and so I am, and yet I love it.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: I had heard 'em say forsooth, that melancholy people are like spaniels.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why prithee?

sp.speaker: Bets.
sp.p: They say a spaniel, the more a man beats him the more he fawns upon him; so melancholy people, methinks , the more the humour torments 'em the more they love it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: 'Tis very true, come reach me my lute — prithee sing Betty.

div.head: A song.
div.l: Be not so cruel fairest boy,
But unstring thy golden bow,
In love we must expect no joy,
Nothing there but sorrow's flow;
If thy flaming arrow did
But touch, yet it still appears,
We must for ever after bid
Farewell joy, and welcome tears;
Tell us, then tell us where doth grow,
The herb that cures the wounded eye,
Else we must cry alas and woe,
There's no such herb that grows, and die.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: 'Twas well sung.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p:
No indeed forsooth my voice is quite gone, chambermaids have occasion you know forsooth now and then to
sit up in the nights when they have business to do, and that spoils a maid's voice quickly forsooth — they knock.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: They're come I vow, run to the door.

div.stage: She runs to door and lets them in.
Enter Valentine, Fairefaith, Sportlove, Trash the three gentlemen salute Sabina.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: My little Tewxbury mustard, how does thou do?

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p: Mustard? why mustard, pray ye?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Because I never come near thee, but thou makes my very eyes water.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Sir, 'tis fit we now withdraw; the darkness of the night persuaded our attendance, now common civility requires our absence — pleasures attend your proceedings sir.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Sweet night embrace ye sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Thanks noble sir, peace conduct ye.

div.stage: Exeunt Fair. sport. Betty.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Well now your worships pleased I hope — but stay, where's Betty?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: She's gone out with the gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Gone out with the gentlemen quoth 'a? and I stand here.

div.stage: Exit Trash.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your courteous invitation makes some recompense for the late scorn with which you did slight my honest zeal.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: I do acknowledge sir
The error of my rashness, and beg pardon,
I have informed my judgement better since;
And you appear to my opinion
More acceptable far than when you first
Presented your desires with yourself,
That now shall want no fitting entertainment
To satisfy the first neglect.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I cannot deny, but that it made 〈…〉
Of some sad thoughts within me, but I 〈…〉
A little rectified, consideration
Hath almost cured my passions, and my fire
Of love is some what abated.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: The few hours
are added to my age, since you last saw me,
Have made no wrinkles yet upon that beauty,
To which you then did give large attributes,
And to be cold so soon, argues 'twas only
Your flattery and courtship.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Not so lady,
I never dissembled any false intents,
My words were the true characters of my thoughts,
Only your scorn, — there 'tis.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Sir I am altered much
From that bad humour, and my heart hath ta'en
A flame into it from the observation
Of your complete deservings, and is ready
To answer your desires.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: You engage me
To a due gratitude, but I have settled
New resolutions.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Sir, ye are now revengeful,
And punish scorn with scorn; a gentle nature
Would not deny a reconciliation
Upon such terms; but you suspect my freeness.
I blush to think on't, and am sorry sir,
The offer of myself is no more valued,
Than thus to be refused, straight my servant
Shall be your guide, and so I wish sweet peace
To your fair thoughts. She offers to go, he brings her back.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: They are the fairer, lady,
In that they have called back your fairest self
To be their object.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Call not back your humour
To flatter me.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: By my best hopes I do not;
A saint's devotion 〈…〉 earnester,
Or more free from hypocrisy hypocrisy than my love:
I own not a desire but what is yours;
And if again you chide my forward zeal,
My danger will be more in the relapse,
Than in the first disease which you have cured;
in steed of healing balms, apply no corrasives
To my sick heart, but gently entertain
My second motions, for next to eternity
You are my happiness.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: You did intimate
That you had fixed upon some other beauty,
From whose pure excellence, a brighter flame
Is shot, than my dull eyes can sparkle forth;
If it be so I shall not envy it.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Your error
Was a just motive I confess, but when
I said I had settled new resolutions,
I did but dissemble, which pray pardon first,
And then receive me to your fair opinion,
By all the sacred powers, religious mortals
Invoke to make an oath of power to force
Belief, you only must be she,
Or none; in whose blessed union I shall joy,
And satisfy my kindred's expectation
Of issue.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Urge no more,
My faith takes all for truth, and in exchange
Of your dear self, delivers up myself as freely.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: This blessed minute doth deserve
A note in times large register.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Tomorrow
Let it have public motion 'fore our friends;
And when you please the consummation
Of our full joys shall follow: dear, farewell,
I must to bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I will go with ye sweet —

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Forbid ye chaste directors of my soul,
Desire should be so forward ere the ceremonies
Confirm it lawful.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Why should we be nice,
And stand upon the outside of our actions
More than the substance, though we should anticipate
those pleasures, since our vows are past we need not
Have scruple, they'll beget a second doubt,
And make the earnestness of love suspected.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: O fie upon't sir, do not cloud your virtue
With such a stain, you're lovely to me yet,
And shall be whilst you're faithful — I'll to bed
And wish you rest.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good night.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Are ye a man?
And would not take
A better leave of me? Exit Sabina looking back.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: How looking back, and leaving open the door,
I'll leave you such an earnest, if I can
Prevail, that you shall swear I am a man.

div.stage: Exit after her.

div.head: Actus tertius.
div.stage: Enter Fairefaith, Sportlove, and Trash.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: My cousin Valentine not yet returned, say ye?

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Not yet indeed sir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What d'ye think should be the reason?

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: 'Tis not revealed to me sir; but I think he prevailed with his mistress for a night's lodging, and that may be the cause of his long stay.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: He has stayed something long indeed, but — I believe he will come home very shortly forsooth.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: I confess I long to be acquainted with the issue of his enterprise.

div.stage: Enter Valentine, Betty, Trash runs to him.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O my sweet master's come again.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am so.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: And you are even as welcome sir, as ever poor master was to a servant.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: — Prey sweet heart return, let not me trouble ye.

sp.speaker: Bett.
sp.p:
No trouble sir, — if you have any other commands
to impose, I shall joy t'observe 'em.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not I sweet heart, only fare ye well. Exit Betty.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O my sweet honeysuckle, art thou gone already.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good stars, gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Fair morning to my sweet cousin, we hope health betides your mistress, and do now expect to be gladded with the news of a fair progress to the end of your desires.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: The end of my desires is even the desire of my end, for I have no joy on earth.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What again in these perplexities, whence come these clouds of discontent now? — ye took no joy before because ye had no hope t'enjoy her, in whom ye had placed all your hopes and joys, the cause of that distempers removed, what may occasion this — heavens know.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Ye cannot tell sir, perhaps the letter was dissembled, and she in some idle humour might send for him to abuse him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O cousin Fairefaith, this gentlewoman —

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What? cannot she love yet?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes — love? O yes.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Whence rise these distractions then?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Even from her love.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: How? can neither frowns nor smiles give ye satisfaction, 'tis some what strange, two mere contraries should produce the very same effect.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: She has with love undone herself and me.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: There's some mystery in't without question.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: I pray sir untie these knotty expressions, for I cannot.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: To be too prodigal of that, which once lost, the whole world cannot recover — weakness intolerable admit I urged her,
sp.l: I'd thought the treasures not of earth or sea
Cud have persuaded such a brave born mind,
Unto the pleasures of forbidden sheets.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: O sir, is the wind in that corner now?

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: What d'ye think of my opinion now sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O cousin Fairefaith, had I been a woman —

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: You would have been an arrant whore in my conscience. Aside.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I say, if I had been a woman cousin,
Armies of virgin resolutions should
Have still environed me:
Oh misery!
Had she been cautious in preserving that,
That rien of immortality her honour;
Earth had not carried such a paragon;
But now
Her outward frame sets but the blacker dye
Upon her mind's deformity; I'm now resolved
To hate those very thoughts that pitch upon
So pure a piece of impurity.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Puh, what needs all this stir master, suppose ye have found her to want a grain or two, do but consider of it, 'tis nothing amongst friends; alack a day sir, the goldsmith himself may be cozened with a light piece, an't shall please your worship.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: But will not ye visit her again?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Never — never.

sp.speaker: Spo.
sp.p: Nor send to her?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, neither myself, nor any one depends on me shall ere come there again.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O poor Betty, I shall never see thee again, I perceive that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come cousin, I must be gone.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, I shall entreat to be excused,
I have engaged myself to meet a friend,
Which will expect me here immediately.
Farewell cousin. Exeunt Val. sport. Trash.

div.stage: Trash turn, again

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: D'ye hear sir?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Come, what say you?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I have a strange thing come just now into my head sir, and that's this sir; there's Newgate for thieves, Bridewell for whores, and bedlam for mad-folks, yet among all these I do wonder there's never a place for fools.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p:
'Twere a charitable foundation had a man means to do't with, your master has an estate, and might do well to
think of such a thing.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Ye say right sir indeed; charity should begin at home, that's the truth on't — but let me tell ye sir, this gentlewoman does a little trouble my scull for all that.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What a capcase were I in, if her sister should be of the same stamp, what would the world say, what would men think?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What? — they would think ye were born when the sign was either in Aries, Taurus, or Capricorn, that's all they would think for ought I know, and so fare ye well. Exit Trash.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Children and fools tell truth, well
If't be my fate, there's no remedy,
Nor friend to fly unto in such a case
But honest patience. Enter Mirabell.
Stay, here she comes, I'll see,
If in her carriage I can read my fortune
— what my Mirabell — unexpected happiness.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: How d'ye sir?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Better then I was.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Why? were ye sick sir?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Suppose I had been, or am, your presence would beget a health immediately, i confess I was not even now so well as now I am, because I wanted thee which now I have sweetest.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I should be loath to be found wanting, when your occasions call upon my service sir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sweetly spoken fair Mirabell,
But hear me,
Admit I had a strange occasion now
To try thy bosom, wouldst thou be content
To run a hazard that might manifest
Thy love and loyalty?

sp.speaker: Mir
sp.l: There's not a danger in the world can be
So dreadful to my thoughts, but I would run
T'embrace it for the pleasure of my love;
But pray sir, what mean these doubts?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Nothing fair one, only a conceit.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: May it concern me sir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Yes — 'tis but a thing incident to all your sex.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Please you to unlock your mind sir,
I'll study what I can to purge your thoughts.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: 'Tis only this — I fear you are too coy,
That's all my fear, too coy Mirabell, too coy,

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Coyness! O heavens! 'tis the only object of my scorn sir ,
I do not think there's such a thing ith' world,
Or that kind nature
Was e'er the mother of so vile a monster;
Were I persuaded that my veins contained,
But the least dram of such a peevish humour,
Though't kept my heart alive I'd rinse it out;
In a word I disdain it.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: My hopes say you do.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, if you please,
Put your invention to the rack,
Till it find out some strange device to try
Whether I'm coy or no;
Breath but a syllable, and it straight commands
The mind or person to serve
Your pleasures.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: There's not a tittle of a word in this,
But has its choir of harmony;
But why do I defer so great a bliss?
Come, let love embraces crown our sweet desires.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What d'ye mean sir?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Only a gentle taste of love's delicious sweets.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What, before we marry?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Your reason.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: O it puts life into a patient expectation — come.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Pray forbear sir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: How? forbear?
What's become of this present minutes protestations.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: I never dreamed that you
Had ever sullied your well tutored soul
With such a vile intention.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Come, come, where twining hearts unite
What need these scruples?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir,
Stain not your breast with such ignoble thoughts,
'Tis true —
I scorn proud coyness, but I do abhor
To think of this.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: O that those eyes
Should be the portals to a heart of flint,
I cannot endure it;
Come, come, I must needs satisfy my flames.
Therefore no more excuse.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Sir, ye have uttered words
Do breathe an air would kill a basilisk;
Call ye this love?
'Tis rather treason 'gainst love's majesty ▪
Will you pretend t'express a love to me,
And yet speak ruin to my reputation;
Banish these thoughts, or else for ever be
A detestation to my bosom.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Dwell in thy goodness, gentle love;
'Twas not to please a wanton appetite,
Or spot thy shrine of virgin purity
That I have spoke;
No it was only but to try the strength
Of thy resolves in goodness, what before
I did but love, I now admire;
But —
If like thy sister thou hadst swerved a jot,
From that integrity wherewith I see
Thy mind is fortified, I should have cut
Thee off from my acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: How's this? if like my sister, say ye?
What has she done, pray ye?

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: No great hurt forsooth.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: If ye love me tell me sir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p:
Now ye conjure me, I will. My cousin Valentine Crambagge that was so in love with her, it seems he prevailed with her a little too much, to give it ye
in plain terms he has lyen with her, glutted himself with the sweet spoils of her virginity, and now for ought I hear by the virtue of hocus-pocus , my gentleman's gone.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Accursed fate, Sabina thus dishonoured,
And by thy kinsman?
I fear too much of that detested blood
Flows in thy veins, henceforth I'll not converse
Either with thee or any other man
That is of kindred to him, pray ye be gone,
Your presence turns my very stomach up,
Take't as ye please, I must for e'er discard ye.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Displeased with me for his faults?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: 'Tis all one, speak not — reply not — your sentence is this — fare ye well.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: I obey it —Exit Fairefaith.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It has been still observed since time begun
That sweetest natures still are soonest won,
This is the fate that usually attends
Best dispositions:
Poor women! into how many fools paradises are we daily brought by these wicked men!
Ah poor sister.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How now, what ails your sister now?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Nothing forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What does the wedding hold or no? — ha?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: She's wedded already sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How? and I not know on't? what a forward saucy girl's this?
But is she married indeed?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, to misery, shame, and infamy.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What's the matter girl? — ha? — speak — what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: He that pretended so much love to her, I mean young Crambag.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Ay — what of him? — ha? what's the business I say?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O sister, sister!

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p:
Daughter, I charge ye tell me what the matter is,
what of young Crambagge?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: He — that villain has by smooth words wrought upon her gentle nature, to her perpetual dishonour; to tell ye the plain truth sir, he has lyen with her, published it abroad to her disgrace, and is now fled.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: — umph — lyen with her? — and fled?
Is there no thunder left above the sky?
Is Jove grown deaf? or has he sworn to lie
Asleep , and thus forget the earth? Enter Trash.
What's your business sirrah?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Sir, my master sent me to your worship, to tell your worship, that your worship needs not trouble yourself about your daughter's portion, for his minds altered, and he bid tell your worship that he would entreat your worship to have patience.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Sirrah, your master's a rascal, and you are another.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: O by no means, and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: O Mirabell, methought I had a good opinion of him, he had so civilised her, and methought had brought her to be the best natured girl:
sp.l: Merciless fate,
My passive fortitude wherewith I once
Outfaced misfortune now is fled and gone,
My daughter thus disgraced?
What's the reason I knew't no sooner?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: It comes too soon whensoever sir;
The messenger has heels of lead that brings
Good news, but ill news fly with eagles wings.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Stand fast ye weak supporters of my age
Henceforth my hand be pillow to my head,
Oh my perplexed soul!
Cud I but leap now from some rocky top,
Into the plunging swallow of the sea,
'Twould be some ease,
Fetch her Mirabell, fetch her,Exit Mirabell.
Alas I little dreamed of this.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p:
Your worship might have dreamed on't, for to my knowledge your worship was asleep in your bed when the
business was done.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: O that I had the rogue by the ears.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I but he does not desire to give ear to ye.

div.stage: Enter Mirabell, with Sabina very pensive

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Out ye strumpet, ye whore, does thou play the whore and look me in the face? hast thou played the baggage? hast thou played the whore? — ha? Out of my sight ye quean, get ye out. Exit Sabina.

O Mirabell is there no stones, nor water, fire nor sword to be revenged with — ha? Enter hilts.come sir, you keep a fine order here, I appoint you to over see my house, and you let gentlemen come in and lie revelling here all the night, you are a trusty trojan you.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: 'Tis more than I know sir, 'tis the first time I heard on't, if I had seen the saucy rascals I would have sent 'em further with a vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Abominable — thus to disgrace herself and me, where is she, did not I bid ye fetch her?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: She has been here sir, and you sent her out again.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Has she? I know not, these distractions do so confound me, that I forget the last minute: oh daughter Mirabell what should I do?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: methinks your worship should keep always a rope about your house against such a desperate case as this is.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Hilts take that rogue, and d'ye hear, deliver him from me to the keeper of Bridewell — take him away I say.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Come sir come, are ye come hither to jeer?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: No sir, I did not jeer sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Take him away I say.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Come along come.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Master hilts, your master does but jest man.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Sir your master has abused my house, and I'll make him smart fort.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Tis like enough and please your worship, but shall I be punished for the wickedness of my master's codpiece, and please your worship, no no.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Carry him away I say.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Your worship's a merry gentleman, you love to make sport I see that.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Hilts, I bid you once more carry him away, what d'ye think to laugh me out of my resolutions?

sp.speaker: Hilts,
sp.p: Come your way's sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Hilts is in sober sadness and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: So am I too sirrah, carry him I say —

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Was thou mad to talk thus to a justice of peace, a justice of corum horum rotulorum? 'tis as much as thy life's worth.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: A prating saucy rascal; carry him away.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I beseech your worship forgive me, good your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Carry him away I say.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Good your worship forgive me, I beseech your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Well, let him go for this time, get ye gone sirrah.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yes and shall please your worship — gone quoth 'a? I'll see your worship hanged before I'll come near ye again.

div.stage: Exit Trash.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: O hilts, this wicked fellow has undone us.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Who d'ye mean sir? Mr. Crambagge?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: The same.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: What has he done sir?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What? my cheeks would burn to speak it, uncontrollable fates — is there no pity in your votes.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.l: Well, if I once meet with him —

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I'd make him an example to all the young lads in England, I would fustinado the carcase of him till the limbs of the rogue flew one from another, and then I would beat 'em together again.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: No, no, if we should hurt him hilts, the law would be of his side.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Hurt him, no forsooth, I would only bestow a little timber upon the shoulders of him.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p:
Pish, pish, come, go your ways to my cousin Muchcraft the attorney, tell him I'm coming to him for
his advice; in the mean time do you put the case to him for coming into the house at an unseasonable time of the night, go your ways, I'll be with ye presently.

div.stage: Exeunt sir Tim. and Mir. at one door, hilts at another.
Enter Valentine and Fairefaith.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Your father's coming after us here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Where is he? Enter sir Plent.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: O son — I have been so abused — nay, and a hundred to one but I had been soundly basted too, and all this to please thee.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: As how pray sir?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I went to treat with sir Timothy about the marriage, and because I stood upon a portion, old testy was pleased to call me a thousand rascals; and in the heat of the business (Oh my arms!) comes me in that same great horse-boned hilts, and so shakes me; well son, I'll even walk in, if anybody come to pay money tell 'em I'm within, if they come for money, tell 'em I'm not well, for this fellow has so bruised my arms that I'm not able to tell it; d'ye hear what I say, to ye son? Exit Valentine saying nothing as displeased.nay lower and pout till doomsday, 'tis all one, I will have money before I give my consent, come, come, tell me no more tales — love quoth 'a? If I had married for love cousin, I had been a rogue, a fool, a beggar; no, no son, I must have money, and I will have money.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Sir, the last night your son went to see his mistress, and prevailed so far with her, that to tell you the naked truth, they lay together all night; he perceiving her so easily won to wantonness, and fearing hereafter she might be a little too liberal of her entertainment, has cast her quite off now fears your displeasure for his too much forwardness, and that's the cause of his sadness.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: How? lay with her — 'tis not possible.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Not for a gentleman to lie with a handsome wench, why, 'tis one of the possiblest things that can be sir.

sp.speaker: Sio P.
sp.p:
I'm sorry to hear it cousin, but I'm glad he has put her off, a company of rascals, they are served well enough,
I warrant ye, the poor boy hearing how her father had abused me, cud not find in's heart to love her a jot longer; yet for all that cousin, I like not's humour in this, that he cannot talk with a woman but he must be jobbing presently, I do not like that I must tell ye — well 'tis done and passed now.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: I but I'm afraid you'll hear on't again, sir Timothy intends to clap him up till he has made satisfaction, but pray sir voice it not that I told ye.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Will he so? tell him, I'll see him hanged by the neck in the high way to Paddington first; he clap him up? he shall not have so much as a hair of his head except it were to choke himself with, and yet my son shall go up and down, ay, and job him upon the nose too and he shall not know him; and if you please tell him, that I'm resolved before I have done with him, so bitterly to vex him, that he shall be glad to come with a rope in's hand, and make a humble petition to the hangman, that he may have licence to hang himself to save his clothes — come along. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Mirabell, Kate.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Not vex?
Why? Do you think there is a woman lives.
That has a sister abused as mine
And not yet be vexed? To them Fairefaith.
To bring a maid into this misery,
And all under love's pretence:
This is your kinsman sir, your own flesh and blood sir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: The more sorry am I forsooth;
But if you'll please to entertain my vows,
Of real love and service once again
Into your better thoughts, I'll use a means
That shall preserve her honour from the dust,
If not abhor me.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Let your heart and tongue but correspond
And you enslave my soul.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: I have already hammered in my scull,
A vindication that shall make her name
Shine to posterity.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: The boundless ocean of your goodness drowns
The slender mite of what I can return.
Here she comes, if ye can do her a favour,
Both she and I will be glad to snatch all
Opportunities to express our thankful minds sir.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Ladies, thus it is, he has disguised himself, goes in woman's apparel, if ye please I'll bring ye to him, where, if there be occasion, you shall command my best assistance.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Pray ye sir where is the place?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: It is at a shoemaker's house in the strand, but that's all one, follow me. Exeunt omnes.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Budget. Enter Muchcraft, Budget.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: Sir.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Have ye drawn William woodcocks plea to Tristram Widgrom's declaration — ha?

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: No sir, the cause is removed, woodcock fearing to be overthrown at common law, comes with a pitiful long bill, makes a case of conscience on't, and so is flown away.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Is he so? if I had known that budget, I would have plucked his feathers a little first, but 'tis no matter, let him go. Enter hilts legging and scraping.what's your errand fellow?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Fellow? Sir I'm none of your fellows, not I.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: I believe ye are not, what's your business before me?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Sir I do not come to do my business before you.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: What mean these frivolous answers? Whose man are ye sir?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: My master's sir.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Very good — what mad man are you pray?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Mad sir, no more than yourself — mad sir? — umph.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay let him alone budget, we shall have a brave action of battery here by and by.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Sir, I belong to the right worshipful sir Timothy testy; my master sent me for your vice, the case is this; a gentleman comes into my master's house at an unreasonable time of the night contrary to my masters known will and command, whether is this a trespass or no?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p:
No, no, prithee do not trouble me, I'm a little
busy. Enter sir Tim.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Cousin Muchcraft, how d'ye sir?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir Timothy testy, you are kindly welcome sir, how d'ye sir?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Never worse cousin, — even almost dead with grief, most abominably abused.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Wherein, pray ye sir? Gives him a fee.

sp.speaker: Sir Tim.
sp.p: That I will tell more at large hereafter sir, not only a piece, but my whole love attends ye sir — the case is this; a gentleman comes into my house, at an uncivil and unseasonable time of the night, contrary to my known will and command; a trespass or no?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: A trespass: a transcendent crime sir; a most foul matter, I'll assure ye; your man did not put the case to me in this manner.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Not? ye whoreson blockhead, are ye not able to speak to a man? wherefore do I keep ye? — ha?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: I cud not, I had not instructions in my pocket.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: 'Tis well enough sir, both law and equity supports your cause; come, we'll walk out and talk of it.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Your tongue drops honey cousin, and you have revived my staggering spirits:
sp.l: And now though time and age,
Cover my head with honourable hairs,
Yet —
Since rays of sunny thoughts peep out again,
I'll strive to quell these passions — come
Sad sighs, and tears are orators of grief,
But 'tis an active brain that brings relief. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Actus quartus.
div.stage: Enter Fairefaith, Sabina in man's apparel, Sportlove, Trash, and hilts.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come, pray sir do not think on't.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: How shall I stand by and see.
A gentlewoman of my kindred wronged?
Be patient?
And my kindred thus abused? my proper flesh
And blood disgraced, our reputation turned
Quite topsy-turvy , nay, and all this done
By a lascivious villain?
No, no,
Nothing but's blood shall pacify my sword;
Had but the slave as many thousand lives
As there do grains of sand surround the sea,
There would be scope to vent my fury on;
But now 'tis circumscribed within the verge
Of one poor rascals life, whose blood will scarce
Give satisfaction to my thirsty steel:
Come sir, I do perceive you know his haunts,
Which if ye do,
I do conjure ye here to bring him forth;
And if you will, or dare to second him,
I'll stand ye both.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, on my life I vow,
The place of his abodes unknown to me;
They say he's fled and gone:
'Tis true, I had
Some conversation with him, but I was
A stranger to his thoughts and actions;
And where this time he does bestow himself
'Tis not known to me.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Sirrah, what say you? where's your master?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Ah, I would I cud tell ye, he has left me in a pitiful case here, if old sir plenteous do not take pity upon me, I must even go and drive wheelbarrows in lincolnes-inne-fields, for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Alas poor fellow, I'm sorry for that, what canst do?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I have a quality sir, but the world now adays does not respect men of parts.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: What is't?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: A bagpiper, an't shall please your worship,

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: A bagpiper?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yes indeed sir, as simple as I stand here, I have played before as good bears as be in the kingdom of England.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Where dost live now?

div.stage: Enter Valentine in women's apparel.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Sir, in the mean time i wait upon the lady that lies in the house here.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Trash.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Come ye hither.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Unhappy eyes ye have undone my heart.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I come forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Stay fair one, stay,

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Speak ye to me sir?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: I do,
But first, I do entreat you will be pleased
To smile upon my rashness, then must I
Perforce inform ye, that just now I felt
A blow upon my heart, which I conceive
Was darted from your eyes.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Your conceit was in an error sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: O no,
I see betwixt those breasts
Is Adon's garden, and Elysium's love,Kisses her,
And from these lips proceeds an air transcends
Sabean spices, or the phoenix nest;
Lady,
Be pleased to let this jewel pride itself
Between those snowy hills, and you engage
My soul unto yourself. Gives her a jewel.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: My gratitude entertains your loving directions sir, a word sir,Valen ▪ and sport ▪ go aside.what gentleman is this? methinks he much resembles Sabina testy, know ye him not?

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Not I, I met him here by chance, it matters not who 'tis, take you his gifts — and be sure to yield what he would have ye do, and we shall want neither gold nor jewels, I see that: and d'ye hear, you will by this means put such a trick upon your sweetheart's champion as never was, — and in the issue it will be found to be but a jest, there's and end.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray accept of this.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I were to blame if I should not sir; wheelbarrows, quoth 'a? I'll see 'em all hanged first, a handsome gentlewoman's service is as good as fee tail, I see that.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: methinks lady, you much resemble a gentleman I know, one Mr. Valentine Crambagge, one that I would be every glad to see.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I know the gentleman sir, he is, I take it, a friend to one mistress Sabina testy.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: A friend,
Had she been dead when first she saw his face,
She had been happy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray you why sir?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Has done her that dishonour,
That time can never raze out of memory;
And in regard she is my nearest cousin,
The sad remembrance of it tears my heart
Into a thousand shivers;
But now your presence like the morning sun
Drives off these melancholy mists wherein
My soul did sometimes wander.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I am yours.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: O the sweetness of those words!

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, there's a pound of sugar almost in every word she speaks sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Let's mix ourselves.
But first, let Hymen with a wedding knot
Knit up our souls.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O no sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nay you are now my captive.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I hope I shall easily procure my redemption.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Thy very hearts thy ransom, nothing shall,
But only that redeem thee.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I doubt not sir, but your own goodness will plead my excuse;
For know, I did
Set up a resolution long ago,
Never to marry.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Pish.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: How, not marry?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Remember what I told you cousin; sir, I know she will be persuaded, but that gentlewomen, ye know, think it a kind of disparagement to be too soon won, that's all sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Pray express your intentions lady.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I have already sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: And is that your resolution?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Indeed it is sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Why then I'll tell ye mine:
I'm now in quest of this detested slave
That wronged my cousin, and do hope ere long
To vindicate her quarrel, therefore know,
If thou'lt not marry me immediately,
Those looks that do so much resemble his,
Shall whet my sword against thee, nay, convert
My love to fury, and shall sacrifice
Thy blood, to expiate my kindred's wrong;
Therefore I must, nay more, I will enjoy;
Despite of fate I will;
My quike desires do chide my patience,
And thou must yield or die, than quickly speak;
I cannot stand to wait upon discourse:
But by the way consider, that ye are now
To give a sentence either of life or death,
Upon yourself, take heed; if ye say aye,
You live my darling, but if no, you die.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I consent to marry, and am content to be disposed of as you shall please.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Your breath is music now, come let's along.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why, but sir, you will not carry away my mistress I hope in this manner, will ye? and I have but newly got her neither — slid, these are tricks indeed?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Sirrah, there's for you hold you, your peace, it is my humour. Gives him money.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Bless your worship sir, and keep ye in this humour still say I. Exeunt omnes.

div.stage: Enter sir plenteous, Muchcraft, Budget.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p:
Well sir, I hear ye, but ye have not spoke tooth
purpose yet.

sp.speaker: Sir p ▪
sp.p: Accept this from me sir, I'll prove sir, that my son was invited and sent for, and that her maid and she both used all means possible to allure him thither. Gives him a fee.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Ay, now you have spoke home sir, this is something now, I feel your cause a little better ▪ and thus much for your comfort, never trouble yourselfEnter sir Timothy standing privately to hear the passages, chasing and stamping.about it, I'll take such a course that his cause shall never proceed I'll warrant ye, alas sir Timothy's cause is not worth the leg of a fly, and yet he does so torment my house, that I can neither eat, drink, nor sleep; ye know budget how often I have desired him to forbear my house ▪ and yet all will not do.

sp.speaker: Bud.
sp.p: I wish he were hanged, he makes me tell a hundred lies in a week in telling him ye are not within, of purpose to be rid of him.

sp.speaker: Sir. T.
sp.p: Here's a rogue.

sp.speaker: Much.
