sp.p: Alas for's business, were my case, if anybody would but give me a saucer of mustard for't, he should have it.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Saucy rascal.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Suppose he brings his action, what can he do in 't? — not this, 'tis true, he would have retained me to have taken out a writ against ye, but when I perceived that it was nothing but a malicious humour, I bid him go and be hanged with this brabbles ▪ I would not be troubled with 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir ▪ T.
sp.p: Very good, but you were willing enough to be troubled with my money, I have heard you all this while, and this your sucking knave too.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Sir Timothy, come, come, I'm glad you are come, I'm glad you are here with all my heart, come, I must have you made friends by all means.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Friends? I'll see him stand bare to the tail of a cart first, I friends with him? — hang him rascal.

sp.speaker: Sir. P,
sp.p:
Sir, I make no doubt but I shall make you know, and your daughter too before I have done with her, that she has abused my son, I cannot tell, I will not say she has bewitched him, but if I prove it, I'll make ye all stink with a
vengeance.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Why, ye worm-eaten slave, does my daughter look like a witch?

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Budget, pray ye put down worm-eaten slave, and the day of the month too, be here?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Didst not come thyself (You whoreson gull ▪)

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Write ye whoreson gull.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Yes sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Didst not come, thyself, I say to know what portion I would give her? Now I find it was but a mere pretence, ye cheating rogue you.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: Write ye cheating rogue you.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: If my man hilts were here I would beat thy very nose into thy face, and afterwards beat it out again.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: What would ye do sir?

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay pray gentlemen forbear while ye are in my house.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.p: I can forbear him no longer.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Come sit Timothy, pray go along with me.

sp.speaker: Budg.
sp.p: Sir plenteous, pray ye go along with me sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Prithee let me beat the rogue first.

sp.speaker: Much.
sp.p: Nay come sir, come, come.

div.stage: Exit Muchcraft with sir Thomas, Budget with sir Plen.
Enter Sabina, Valentine, Fairefaith, Sportlove, Trash, Rowland.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Why so?
This is the crown of all our joys on earth,
When love and marriage trip it hand in hand,
It makes the mind to vault
And caper o'er the clouds of discontent;
Methinks my soul has wings and I cud fly,
From hence to Elysium, come cheer up my sweet,
What art thou sad, and see thy husband laugh?
Come now we are married, we must have but one
Passion betwixt us — gentlemen what?
Frowns at a wedding?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: How? frowns?
Should a man seem to droop or hang the wings
at such a time, he were far fitter for
T'accompany wild tigers in a wood,
Then to converse with men, the gods themselves
Sing epithalamies, when mortals wed,
If gods are subject to these passions, than
They needs must oversway the hearts of men;
Sir, joys attend ye, may you ever be
As full of joys, as we are now to see
Your happy nuptials:
Pish, be not so sad cousin.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Come leave this dull discourse, and let us fill,
Our active souls up to the brim with joy;

Come,
Sings.
Farewell this company,
If you love sadness,
For melancholy is,
Nothing but madness;
Hang up proud costly clothes,
Pedlars and pack toys;
Let us make the hogsheads weep,
Claret and sack boys.
Are there no fiddlers in this world?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir, I would they would come once, my very heels are up ith' air already methinks in this humour, I cud wish the whole world were a morris dance for four and forty hours outright.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: O thou egregious puppy, if the whole world were a morris dance for four and forty hours outright, what should, nay, what does thou think would the good people of new England do all that while.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: I do think they would pray for a timely cessation of the noise of the superstitious bells hanging about their knees.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: A most damnable witch in my conscience.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come sweetheart, rush up your spirits, put on a resolution to be jocund; think but on what must pass betwixt us two this very night;
sp.l: How I must revel in thy arms, and then
How thou must tumble in my bosom;
And that I know will be enough to purge
sad contemplations.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, pray you excuse me;
Troublesome things do whisper in my ear,
Which for the present i cannot expel.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: Pish.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Do not heed or nursle the least sad thought
At such a time, tell 'em some other time
You'll sit and hear their grievances.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Ay, ay, do so, what? upon your jovial day be sad? but where be these fiddlers?

sp.speaker: Musician
sp.p: We are come sir.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Pray ye play then.
Come, a song, a song.

div.head: A song.
div.l: Joy, health, and pleasure, wait upon
This lovely pair,
May all your days like to this one
Be void of care,
And may those twinkling stars of night
Attend your bed,
That so the bridegroom may get right
Your maidenhead.
And let Arabian odours then
Perfume thy sheets;
Strewing thy chamber once again
With dainty sweets,
Then let these pretty thoughts that move
A flame in Cupid's fires,
Bring ye to bed where you may prove
The things that love desires.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Come, these nuptial rites being done,
It now remains we speed it to the bed,
Where we will arm in arm discourse and act
Loves pretty handy dandies — gentlemen
— speak —
Has not my stars been kind,
To grace my fortunes with so fair a bliss.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, ye enjoy a happiness beyond
Expression or compare.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p:
Nay sir, I'll promise ye this, that as long as she is your wife, no man breathing shall ere bring Actaeon's punishment
upon your head — I will not say what the woman may do, and that's a rare blessing Rowland betwixt you and me, I can tell ye.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Methinks I see
Myself now dandled on the knee of fate.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Sir, you do now embrace
A richer vein than ere the sun beheld,
And I presume none save your only self,
Whose presence is a treasure of enchantments,
Could have prevailed so far with her, whose eye
Never yet cast glance of love upon a man,
Therefore do I pronounce
You th' only minion both of fame and fate.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Nay, you are a happy man, that's certain sir, if all men had such wives, we should have a strange world, for then we should be troubled neither with children nor cuckolds.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Well gentlemen golden slumbers attend ye,
Come fair one, come, we have too long deferred
The love embraces of the marriage bed,
Oh how it raps my soul to think that I
This very hour with my fair love must lie,
Raked up in cinders, love may burn, but when
It ''gins to flame, it fires both gods and men;
Come.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Pray ye sir forbear a little.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: I will sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Cousin Fairefaith, a word, you have brought me here upon a business will utterly disgrace me; what will this gentleman think of me d'ye think, when he finds that I have gulled him thus.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.l: Come, come, put your feats to sleep,

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nay, come sweetheart, why these delays?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Pray ye sir deal gently with her, she's young and fearful to lie with a man, and that's the business sir, that makes her so loath t'unpin.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Alas poor soul, in my conscience you had rather lie with a woman, than with these rude men behalf, would not ye forsooth?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, give me your hand.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Good sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Why? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Nothing? I know 'tis something; are not you well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What's the reason ye will not go to bed then? pray ye come without more ado.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Fie upon't cousin, a woman would scorn these things.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Nay, ye are ith' right sir, I do believe she would defy it.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come, what's the business with ye? will ye not go to bed — ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I'll consider of it presently.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: How, consider of it?
Am I a man? A married man? or what?
Am I a husband? must a husband then
Entreat his wife?
Is nature grown so old she has forgotten
To teach her children what belongs unto
Their different places?
Although before I was content to bend
My spirits to your foot, yet know, that now
The will of fate has destined me to be
Next under it the sole, commander of
Your mind and person, therefore now I must,
Nay, I will be obeyed.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Pray ye do not fright her too much, she's a very tender hearted thing forsooth — pray ye speak her fair.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Hold you your prating sirrah, she shall observe my will now.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: You'll never do good sir with foul means.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: By your favour my friend, I know this out of my own knowledge, that a froward sharp husband will presently make a woman do what she list.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Stop your mouths.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p:
Sir, for my part I will not stop my mouth, I understand
what I say sir, I'm a married man myself sir, and 'tis well known to be true, that I cud never yet get any thing of my wife by harsh words.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Once more I bid you hold your babbling.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Sir, she shall not go to bed till she has a mind to go to bed, nor I will not hold my babbling neither sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Hold your peace trash.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: You'll close your mouth by and by I hope.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes marry will i sir, but not at your bidding sir: what now — what d'ye think I'm a fool in a play?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Will you hold your tongue or no?

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes forsooth and please your worship.

div.stage: Sabina takes hold of him, and offers to strike him.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: This insolence I cannot bear,
And for your part you are my wife, and one
In whom obedience ought to be expressed,
And I your top.

sp.speaker: Trash.
sp.p: Ay, you want but a little whipping.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: What say you sirrah?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I say, a woman that has a good husband, and all things else, and will not go to bed, wants nothing but whipping.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Well, 'tis thus,
If mild entreaties, nor a gentle fawn;
Nor protestations, nor a husband's love
Can mollify thy stubborness, nor bring
Thy sturdy disposition to my hand;
I'll for a time quite turn out of my thoughts
A husbands pities, and where smiles did fail,
A lusty bastinado shall persuade
— what shall I be baffled thus
Out of my pleasures with a woman's blush;
Is't fit that I stand pleading where my stars
Bid me command? I scorn it, therefore speak
This very present minute, nay before
You fetch more breath, speak either ay, or no,
Or I must strike, there's no remedy.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: We shall have the peace broken, here presently, I see that.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Peace, quoth 'a? nay and my head be not broken I care not.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Come, she is content to go sir.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Give the word.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I will go to bed.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: Come your ways then.

div.stage: Exit Sabina leading Valentine; Trash falls into a laughter.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.l: D'ye hear gentlemen, d'ye hear?
What if this gentleman should get my master with child now?

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.p: Nay, what if your master should get that gentleman with child.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I cannot tell what he may do for men, but I never knew him do such a courtesy for a woman yet.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Mr. Fairefaith, pray tell me one thing, why did you being my master's kinsman, and an old soldier stand so patiently, and see him so affronted.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: I that's true indeed Rowland, he being an old beaten soldier too.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A beaten soldier?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: An old soldier I mean sir.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I confess I had no disposition to meddle in't, because i know they'll agree themselves, I know the bowels of the business, which you do not, come, go along, and by the way I'll tell ye the plot.

lg.l: And then we'll bring this news
To bless the ears of old sir Timothy,
Strength I confess may make a giant yield,
But give me policy to win the field. Exeunt omnes.

div.head: Actus quintus.
div.stage: Enter Mirabell, hilts before, and Kate behind.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: O my poor sister!

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: There's no question but we shall find her, how long has she been wanting forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A great while Kate, a little faster, what shall I tread upon your heels? — not so fast neither.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p:
What the devil ails ye? too soft, and then too fast, here's more ado with you, than with all the pageants in
my lord majors show; he that waits on you, had need to have his steps pricked out with a pair of compasses, for ought I see.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: What a surly groom are you, may not one speak to you?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Speak? yes forsooth you may speak, but I do not love to walk before a gentlewoman like one of these gingerly youths that go before their mistresses, as if the streets were paved with eggs, not I.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Why, how now sir sauce box, what is't all fellows with ye, ye filthy, stinking, saucy, dirty, scabbed, paltry, lousy, mangy rogue ye.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Heyda, mistress juniper, what's the matter with you trow? you were not used to be so snappish, I'm sure on't, I have both gone and rid before you, and you never found fault with it.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: O ye lying rascal, did ye ever ride before me in your life?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Yes marry have I forsooth.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: 'Tis as false a tale mistress as ever was told; 'tis true, he rid before me one night a little short journey; 'twas nothing, I cud even a gone as far a soot upon the matter.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Who doubts that forsooth?

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Why will you lie than ye rascal?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Why, what's the business? what the mischief ails ye? sure ye have not made water today I think.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come hilts come, you should bear with her.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Bear forsooth, she should bear, she's used too 'It, more than I am forsooth.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: What should I bear prey? suffer such an ass as you to ride upon my back, should I not?

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Why not? as well as always upon your belly forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Come, come, pray ye go along, we have something else to think on than stand here.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Very well sir, I shall think upon your words.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: This way forsooth?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Yes, yes, go on.

div.stage: Enter sir Timothy with officers meeting them.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: How now daughter, whether are you going?

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: To see if I can find my sister sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Come, come, do not trouble yourself to no purpose, I have ordered it already, I'll have these men go that have authority to make the doors and gates fly open where they come and go, and d'ye hear officers, look too 'It, and be sure to search very narrowly the places that I told ye of, and especially the house where young Crambagge is suspected to lie, and if ye find either one or both of 'em, bring 'em away, d'ye hear?

sp.speaker: Officer
sp.p: We shall sir. Exeunt officer.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Daughter, I rather think (To put herself out of th'way of this approaching disparagement) she has run herself upon some desperate course.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: But d'ye think these men will find her sir?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I cannot tell, we shall know presently.

sp.speaker: Kate.
sp.p: Do not weep mistress, I hope she's well, and will be here again shortly.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Come, come, let's have no weeping.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Do not you grieve, and for them 'tis not a pin matter, let them alone, weeping is as wholesome for a woman sir as making of water.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.l: Had she but bid farewell
'Twould not have troubled me so much;
But thus to go away —

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Never fear, she's well enough I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: O hilts,
Her high born spirit cannot brook disgrace,
And I do fear these mischiefs will provoke
Some violent hand upon herself;
Yet methinks one thing
Whispers my understanding in the ear,
And tells me she is safe;
There's not a jewel, ring, or bracelet left
That ere she wore, but is conveyed away.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Nay then sir fear nothing, for if she had so much wit to carry away her rings and jewels, she has wit enough to keep herself from killing or drowning, I warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: O heavens!
With what a swinge is youth,
hurried along the world and subject still,
Unto the rule of an unbridled will:
Oh!
Pity those parents then, who oftentimes
Are brought unto their graves by children crimes;
In, in, and comfort yourself;
I'll see these officers dispatched away,

div.stage: Exeunt hilts, Mirabell, Kate at one door, sir Timothy at the other.
Enter Valentine unbuttoned as out of bed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Rowland, Rowland ▪ Rowland; I say.

div.stage: Enter Rowland as newly awaked.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: What's the matter here?
Wast you that called sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It was I.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: What would ye have sir, are not ye well?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I would I were.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: I'm sorry you are not well sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Call trash, call trash.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Trash, trash.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What's the matter? Within.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.l: Come presently, you master's not well;
He's coming sir, what would ye please to have sir?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing, nothing at all.

div.stage: Enter trash yawning and rubbing his eyes.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Rowland, where art fool?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here, here man, whither dost go?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: What's the matter Rowland — ha?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Your master's not well here.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Not well? O alas! I'll run and fetch some hot water presently.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Stay, whither d'ye go? come your ways hither, what will you fetch man, I'm not sick.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Not? you're but a yawling rascal Rowland for waking of me, I was in the daintiest sleep, and the sweetest dream; methought my master was in bed with the bravest wench —

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Twas too true.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How? was it too true? introth, I thank ye for nothing, you never dreamed so for me I'm sure on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O Rowland, I'm undone, I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Ambo.
sp.p: What's the matter sir?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: I'll warrant ye the gentleman that went to bed with him, finding himself cozened has killed himself, or one mischief or other, I thought no good would come on't.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: No, no, 'twas a woman all the while, 'twas a woman.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: 'Twas a woman good man simple, what? dost thou think that I dream out of Aesop's fables?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: 'twould vex a man to marry in jest, and then to have it prove plain earnest, I'll assure ye that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O trash, I'm undone.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why undone sir, why d'ye say so, and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: I'm married man, I'm married with a vengeance,

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Why so am I too sir; but how should we help it, can ye tell that sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: O Rowland, what shall I do? where shall I go? where shall I run?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Run quoth 'a? nay, if you're married once, I'll trust ye for running.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: I am married, and I know not to whom, did I but know that.

sp.speaker: Trash.
sp.p: That's no great matter, 'tis but going to the church book, and you may know that presently.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Accursed fate, what marriages might I have had? to what a pitch might I have mounted up my fortunes? which now I see are nothing but confusion:
sp.l: Who knows what strumpet this may be,
Some quean for ought I know, that thinks to raise
Herself out of my ruins:
Now my perplexed thought begin to burn
With flames of guilt:
Now comes my trembling soul unto the bar
Of my own knowledge:
Oh Sabina, Sabina!
The gods now tumble vengeance on my head
For wrongs to thee;
Had I been well advised, oh then I might
Have lain by thy fair side, where every touch:
Had been as tender as a bed of down.
And every smile a heaven;
But 'tis too late,
To call back what is past, it was my fate,
And there's an end;
Now am I round entrenched with miseries;
One side a marriage nips me in the bud;
On th'other side, a rancorous enemy,
Old testy, who still gazes on the print
Of our mistaken step, therefore 'tis now
No time to pause, pack up my clothes this night,
I do intend to save myself by flight:
Trash, about it presently.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Yes and please your worship.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: But d'ye hear, let not my landlady, nor her husband have so much as a glimpse of it, for I have no money for 'em.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay sir, if you intend to travel, be sure ye take all your money along with ye, especially if you mean to be merry, for you shall find that money is the most dainty companion sir; but Rowland, d'ye hear? scatter no words.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: By no means.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.l: Not a word sir;
sp.stage: Exeunt Valentine and Trash, manet Rowland.
sp.l: Travel quoth 'a? here's a piece of work indeed:
O Mr. welt, how d'ye sir, how does my landlady — ha?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Very well, how d'ye you Rowland?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Troth, pretty well, servingman like, careless of much, proud of a little, drunk for want of wit, and sometimes sober for want of money.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: I thought ye had been sick, because I have not seen ye this long time.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Sick quoth 'a? my pockets are a little cowardly now and then indeed, that's all my sickness.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: What? would ye have 'em quarrelsome?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Quarrelsome? no, but I would have 'em to have a little more mettle in 'em for all that.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Where's your master pray?

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Nay I know not, I have not seen him this six hours.

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: There is a little money due to me from him, I wish he would take the payment of it into consideration, I have extraordinary occasion to use the money, if he please to let me have but some of it, it will do me a courtesy, he shall find me reasonable.

sp.speaker: Wife
sp.p: How idly you talk husband? Is that a way to live in the world, do you think it is for my ease to have gentlemen come, and lie in my house, and go away and pay nothing — ha?

sp.speaker: Welt.
sp.p: Pay? yes good sweetheart, why should he not pay; there's nobody speaks against that, sweetheart.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Why do you talk so foolishly then of being reasonable, and I cannot tell what, I do not like such words I tell ye truly; — reasonable quoth 'a? Eat my meat, drink my drink, burn my wood, foul my rooms, wear my sheets, make use of my servants, and yet I must be reasonable; if ye can talk no wiselier before folks, pray ye hold your peace and let your wife speak — besides, ye know he owes me both for boots, shoes, and pantables, and I shall give him that too shall not I? no indeed forsooth, I would have your master to know that I do not buy my leather so cheap, I'll assure ye — be reasonable quoth 'a? besides, I have promised to pay Mr. sugarbox the chandler, nutmegs and sugar for his morning's draughts, and Mr. dash the vintner for wine in's chamber, and shall I pay them before your master has paid me — introth I do not mean it.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: 'Tis fit a gentleman should pay you before, that's the truth of it.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Ye say right Rowland, I see you have more consideration with ye than my husband has — be reasonable quoth 'a? — marry whoop.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Why d'ye keep all this stir, my master's not running away woman — here's a quarter indeed, if he will be ruled by me, he shall not give you one farthing, because you keep such a coil.

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p:
How keep such a coil ye jack sawee? how now? such a coil? d'ye think ye are talking to your companions sirrah? such a coil? and in my own house too sirrah? and you
must stand by forsooth like John a Noakes, and see every servingman run upon me in this manner; remember this when ye come to bed; and for your masters not paying of me, ye saucebox, I'm at the better end of the staff with him, for I have locked up all his clothes; nay if you're so saucy, I'll fit him, I'll warrant ye.

sp.speaker: Row.
sp.p: Ye will?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Yes indeed will I?

div.stage: Enter Trash.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Rowland, Rowland, Rowland, thieves, thieves, thieves, thieves, Rowland, thieves.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: How now? how now?

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: All my master's clothes are stolen quite a way Rowland, all stolen every jot, breeches, doublet, boots, spurs, cloaks, gowns, hats, bands, cuffs, ruffs, caps, shoes, shirts, all gone, all stolen, every jot.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here's the thief.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Where? where?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here I say.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Who, my landlady, did you steal my master's clothes — ha? wherefore pray ye?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Steal 'em? no sir i scorn it; I took 'em indeed, and I'll justify it; and more than so sir, I have locked 'em up, and I'll justify that too.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: How? locked up my master's clothes, wherefore I pray ye?

sp.speaker: Wife.
sp.p: Wherefore? do not ye know your master owes me money? do not you know I have often asked it, and cannot get it? do not ye know that it is a pretty sum? do not you know that it is for meat, drink, lodging, fire, and candlelight, washing, wringing, and starching; besides, boots, shoes, pantables, and galosheas: if, I had the book I cud show ye.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay, you're perfect enough without book for ought I see. Enter boy.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Trash, your master's come home, and you must come to him presently. Exit boy.

div.stage: Exeunt Trash, welt and his wife.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Here's a creature I'll swear upon a book, this woman has no bones in her tongue, if any man love trumpets, there's a noise for him, sure I do not think but this shoemaker's a witch, he would never a contracted himself to the devil else.

div.stage: Enter Valentine.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: What, are ye here? and I have nothing put up yet?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sir, your clothes are all put up, and safe under lock and key.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nay then 'tis no matter; who put 'em up?

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: That did my landlady sir, she has locked 'em up, and swears she'll keep 'em safe till she can persuade ye to part with some pocket mettle sir.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Enough, enough, I will not be beholden to her, I'll satisfy her.

div.stage: Enter sir Timothy with officers.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: O sir, have I found ye out in the end, come officers lay hold on him — but stay let's talk with ye a little first.

sp.speaker: Ro.
sp.p: Sure my master was born when the sign was in cancer, for whatsoever he does intend, goes always quite backwards, well somebody shall know on't presently, that shall fetch him off again for all this sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Sirrah, hold your peace, and
Be gone about your business fellow,Exit Rowland.
Dost know what thou hast done? or have my wrongs
Arrived at thy understanding yet? — ha?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir I am conscious to myself of all
The wrongs and injuries that I have done ye.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Why hast thou put this blemish on my child,
Which like a canker threatens to deface
My story, and for ever raze my name
Out of the book of honour, nay, a spot,
Which time nor date, nor all the brinish waves
Can e'er wash out — speak thou detested wretch;
Hadst not a spark of virtue left within
Thy bosom to preserve thy honour — speak, I say.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: In trembling reverence to your precepts here,
I creep upon my knees before the bar
of your just frowns, I dare not plead excuse,
No, no, my crimes are writ upon my front
In die of blushing guilt, which nothing but
Your reconciling smiles can ere wash out,
— they, I say, they must be
That expiating sacrifice for me.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Smiles on thee?
Hast thou the face to say thy faults can be
Capable of mercy? go to, mark what I say,
Unless thou canst contrive a way to cure
The wounded reputation of my girl,
Expect not one commiserating thought,
But all the tortures of severity
That e'er can be inflicted —
Come, come, rise up, it is in vain to kneel,
My ears are stopped to mercy, nothing now
But only that can open them.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sir, I am content to engage all my possibilities to accomplish your desires.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: There may be some hope in this.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, devise how I may
But give this satisfaction you require,
And my soul shall study its performance.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: I cannot tell,
Thou hast so plunged her in a sink of shame,
— that't will, for ought I know,
Nonplus the world to find a remedy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Her case is not so desperate, I hope,
I'm ready here to hug
The most ingenious torments on these terms,
That she and you'll be pleased;
Wert to encounter a whole host of fiends,
Never to sleep but in a dragon's den;
Or from the bowels of the burning hill
To fetch a coal, eat fire, or drink a cup
Of Mercury precipitat, I'll do't,
And think it an Elysium, if it may
Redeem your loves, and state me once again
in your esteem.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: 'Tis well, I do commend your forward mind;
But this will never do't;
There's nothing but a marriage will admit
A thought of remedy.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Nothing but marriage?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Not any thing ith' world but marriage ▪

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Not?

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: No indeed.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Merciless planets, will ye still go on,
To heap these hills of mischief on my neck ▪
Or can misfortune reach a higher pitch
In him whose misery is intolerable,
And remedy impossible, oh no;
Sir, in a word,
Your daughter's quite undone, and so am I.

sp.speaker: Sir, T.
sp.l: How stands the business?
Speak the worst, if truth, and let me die.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis in vain to counterfeit,
Or build up castles where they cannot stand;
Do with me what ye please, the truth is this,
I am already married.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: How? already married?
Villain, keep in that breath;
The repetition of these words would tear
A heart of brass — already married?
Didst thou ensnare my child for this?
Hast thou betrayed her white innocence for this?
Blasted the blossom of her virgin spring,
And married now another?
Canst hope or dream, that e'er thy perjured soul
Shall see th' Elysian groves?
Hold heart from breaking, now or never hold,
Married to another?
Shall I be bandied thus for ever twixt
Rackets of shame and misery,
Cud fate find never a football but myself
To toss and spurn — umph?
Hell and the furies do conspire I think,
To cull out me from all the rest oth' world
To vent their mischiefs on, who is't ye have married? speak.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: It is unknown to me sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I ask ye who 'tis you have married?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Sir,
Upon my life I know not who she is.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Has thy lewdness brought thee to distraction; married, and ye know not to whom? come take him away, 'tis in vain to talk — but stay a little. I'll see what creature 'tis.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: 'Tis very true sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: What wilt thou make me mad?
Where is she, in the house?

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Officer, go fetch her hither,Exit officer.
I'll make her tell me who she is,
If she can:
sp.p: Married already quoth 'a? and ye know not to whom neither, here's a marriage with a vengeance.

div.stage: Enter Fairefaith and Sportlove, who were present at the marriage leading betwixt them Sabina veiled, they present her to her father, hilts attending them.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: We heard ye sent for my cousin Valentine's wife sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: I did so.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.p: We have brought her to you sir, here she is sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: Very well, in good time: what are you gentlewoman? whence are ye? ha? — speak; nay, if you will not give me an account, I must punish ye;Sabina unpins her mask, and falls upon her knees to her father.
sp.l: — let not my eyes surfeit — what my Sabina?
My lovely girl?
Thrice welcome to my bosom?
My Sabina? my daughter, and the wife
Of this my dear friend, unexpected felicity,
sp.stage: Enter sir plenteous with Trash and Rowland.
sp.l: Sir plenteous? welcome thrice noble sir plenteous;
But stay
gentlemen, pray ye present her to her husband first,
sp.stage: Fairefaith and Sportlove present her to Valentine.
sp.l: Sweet sir plenteous, how d'ye sir?

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.p: D'ye know me sir, nay gaze on sir.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: He knows her present I see that.

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Know her? he has been familiarly with her — before man, and that thee didst not know.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Gaze on still sir,
I'm not Sabina's ghost, but her poor self;
Here stands the creature that was wronged by thee,
The very selfsame that you married sir:
What dost thou think?
Dost thou not tremble, lest I should begin,
To number up my wrongs?
I that was lulled ith' bosom of my friends,
And as 'twere dandled on a father's knee;
Forfeited all this favour, and was made
A stranger to his eye for love to thee;
Yet thou
Like the prodigious monster of the world
Ingratitude, didst labour to forget,
Not my love only, but those sacred vows
Have passed betwixt us; but to be short,
Thus — thus I revenge myself. Kisses him.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: O my Sabina!
It is too sweet and loving a revenge
Upon so vile a miscreant.

sp.speaker: Sab.
sp.l: Come
Let the remembrance of these matters die,
And be confined to dust, let 'em be trod
Into the very centre of the earth,
Never to rise again; and let our loves
For ever twine like twins;
What's past I have forgotten and pardoned.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.l: Seal it, or else I die;Kisses him again.
Live, oh live!
A rare example to all future times
Of constancy in love.

sp.speaker: Sir P.
sp.l: Daughter, my heart bids thee welcome,
This night my house shall give thee entertainment,
Whereof thyself shall be sole governess,
And when the icy hand of death shall drive
My soul out of this clod,
It shall be his and thine.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: But gentlemen, methinks I long to hear
The story of this marriage, how it come to pass;
For did I know't, I should adore the star,
Under whose influence she was brought t'arrive
Midst storms of woe upon this shore of bliss.

sp.speaker: Sport.
sp.l: Sir, I do think 'twill be
A seasonable discourse for supper;
Suspend but your desires till then
And you shall be satisfied.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: With all my heart, with all my heart, but son, I have one petition to prefer to you.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: You may style it a command sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.p: You must needs bestow upon me your servant trash.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Heyda? now I'm a begged fool, I see that.

sp.speaker: Val.
sp.p: Sirrah, attend my father.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Your worship's humble servant sir.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: In all this business I have observed in thee
Discretion — judgement — wit — and police;
Therefore
I do appoint thee steward of my house,
And put into thy charge the overseeing
Of all my businesses.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Nay sir, for an oversight in any business let me alone.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: And what is more.
Dispose my house and servants as you please.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: Hilts, come hither — sirrah, do you wait upon me.

sp.speaker: Hilts.
sp.p: Yes forsooth.

sp.speaker: Tr.
sp.p: I did ever think thou wouldst come to some good, for thou hast been always an honest Trojan; d'ye hear, if you had carried me to Bridewell, when ye were bid — where had your proferments been then hilts.

sp.speaker: Sir T.
sp.l: Mr. Fairefaith, for you,
I do perceive your ingenuity,
Has been a means to make my comfort swell;
And for return, i do bestow on thee
My daughter Mirabell.

sp.speaker: Fai.
sp.l: Sir, your returns are far beyond the claim
Of my deserts; and though i am not fit
To bandy favours with so brave a knight,
Yet I will stretch my studes to express
A detestation of ingratitude: and now Sabina,
I do salute thee by the word of sister,Kisses her ▪
— but why so dumpish on a sudden — ha?
I know the cause already, 'tis for fear
Your censures on her faults be too severe;
She has given satisfaction where 'twas due,
Her father's pleased, and so we hope are you:
To you she is referred, who now are set,
Ready to give your sentences; but yet
Be pleased to speak your doom with gentle breath,
Cause you're the judges of her life and death.

div.head: Textual Notes
div.p: The textual notes below aim at making textual corrections readable in their immediate context and facilitating access to the source text. A five-dit number preceded by 'A' or 'B' represents an EEBO-TCP filenumber. A notation like "6-b-2890" means "look for EEBO page image 6 of that text, word 289 on the right side of the double-page image." That reference is followed by the corrupt reading. A black dot stands for an unidentified letter, a black square for an unidentified punctuation mark, a diamond for a missing word, and the ellipsis for a short span of undefined length. The corrected reading is displayed as a kewyord in context.
